question: Longest cutaneous nerve in body ?
prompt:
Longest cutaneous nerve in body ?A)Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
B)Medial cutaneous nerve of thigh
C)Saphenous nerve
D)Sural nerve
output0: The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the longest cutaneous nerve in the body. It runs from the lower back down to the knee and is responsible for sensation in the skin of the thigh and lower leg.
output1: The Medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the longest cutaneous nerve in the body. It arises from the lumbar spinal cord and extends down the back of the thigh, innervating the skin and muscles of the thigh and leg.
output2: The Saphenous nerve is the longest cutaneous nerve in the body, running down the entire length of the leg and innervating the skin of the thigh and foot.
output3: The sural nerve is the longest cutaneous nerve in the body. It arises from the lumbar spinal cord and courses down the back of the leg to the foot. It is responsible for sensation in the skin of the lower leg and foot.

question: Most common cause of acute abdomen in young girl
prompt:
Most common cause of acute abdomen in young girlA)Acute appendicitis
B)ovarian torsion
C)Mitzschmerz
D)Renal colic
output0: Acute appendicitis is the most common cause of acute abdomen in young girls. It is caused by inflammation of the appendix, which can lead to severe pain and other symptoms.
output1: Ovarian torsion is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition that can cause acute abdominal pain in young girls. It occurs when the ovary becomes twisted and cuts off blood flow to the organ. This condition is more common in girls who have not yet reached menstruation, as their ovaries are more mobile and more prone to twisting.
output2: Mitzschmerz is the most common cause of acute abdomen in young girls. It is a sudden and severe pain in the lower abdomen, usually caused by a ruptured ovarian cyst or tumor.
output3: The most common cause of acute abdomen in young girls is actually renal colic, which is caused by a blockage of the ureter.

question: Most common syndrome associated with A-V canal defect -
prompt:
Most common syndrome associated with A-V canal defect -A)Down syndrome
B)Klinfilter syndrome
C)Turner syndrome
D)Marfan syndrome
output0: The most common syndrome associated with A-V canal defect is Down syndrome. This is because Down syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects the development of the brain and body, and it is often associated with congenital heart defects, such as A-V canal defect.
output1: The Klinfilter syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that is often associated with A-V canal defects. It is characterized by a range of symptoms, including cardiovascular and neural tube defects, which can lead to a variety of complications.
output2: Turner syndrome is the most common syndrome associated with A-V canal defect. This condition is caused by a missing or partially deleted X chromosome, which can lead to a range of physical and developmental abnormalities, including heart defects.
output3: The most common syndrome associated with A-V canal defect is Marfan syndrome. This is because Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue, which can lead to heart defects such as A-V canal defect.

question: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-day history of abdominal pain and frequent urination. His mother reports that the patient has wet his bed overnight and that his urine smelled odd this morning. He has been toilet trained for 4 months and has had very few accidents since then. His last bowel movement was 3 days ago. He was born at term after a normal gestation and has reached all developmental milestones. His parents divorced 4 months ago and the patient's father has moved away. The patient began preschool 6 weeks ago. During this period, he has had two upper respiratory infections that resolved without treatment. His 12-year-old brother has type 1 diabetes mellitus. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the abdomen shows mild suprapubic tenderness. Urine dipstick is positive for leukocyte esterase, nitrite, and blood; urinalysis shows white blood cells and gram-negative rods. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
prompt:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-day history of abdominal pain and frequent urination. His mother reports that the patient has wet his bed overnight and that his urine smelled odd this morning. He has been toilet trained for 4 months and has had very few accidents since then. His last bowel movement was 3 days ago. He was born at term after a normal gestation and has reached all developmental milestones. His parents divorced 4 months ago and the patient's father has moved away. The patient began preschool 6 weeks ago. During this period, he has had two upper respiratory infections that resolved without treatment. His 12-year-old brother has type 1 diabetes mellitus. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the abdomen shows mild suprapubic tenderness. Urine dipstick is positive for leukocyte esterase, nitrite, and blood; urinalysis shows white blood cells and gram-negative rods. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this patient's condition?A)Social stressors
B)Constipation
C)Posterior urethral valves
D)Respiratory tract infection
output0: The most likely predisposing factor for this patient's condition is social stressors, specifically the recent divorce of his parents. This can cause emotional stress and disrupt the child's routine, leading to changes in his behavior and potentially causing him to regress in areas such as toilet training.
output1: The most likely predisposing factor for this patient's condition is constipation. The child's symptoms of abdominal pain and frequent urination, along with the positive urinalysis for white blood cells and gram-negative rods, suggest a urinary tract infection (UTI). Constipation is a common predisposing factor for UTIs in children, as it can lead to the development of bacteria in the urinary tract. The patient's recent history of toilet training and the fact that he has had few accidents since then suggest that he may be experiencing some constipation.
output2: Posterior urethral valves are a common cause of urinary tract infections in children, and they are more common in boys than in girls. The patient's symptoms of abdominal pain and frequent urination, along with the presence of white blood cells and gram-negative rods in his urine, are consistent with a urinary tract infection caused by posterior urethral valves. The patient's recent history of constipation may also be a contributing factor, as constipation can lead to an increased risk of urinary tract infections.
output3: The most likely predisposing factor for this patient's condition is a respiratory tract infection, such as a urinary tract infection (UTI). The patient's symptoms of abdominal pain and frequent urination, along with the presence of leukocyte esterase, nitrite, and blood in the urine, are all consistent with a UTI. Additionally, the patient's recent history of respiratory tract infections and the fact that his brother has type 1 diabetes mellitus also support this diagnosis.

question: Jaroslav Heyrovky developed the following technique:
prompt:
Jaroslav Heyrovky developed the following technique:A)Polarography
B)Gas-solid chromatography.
C)Capillary electrophoresis.
D)Polarimetry
output0: The Turtle Technique was developed by Jaroslav Heyrovky. This is a method of polarography, which is a technique used to measure the concentration of ions in a solution.
output1: Jaroslav Heyrovsky developed the technique of Gas-solid chromatography.
output2: Jaroslav Heyrovsky developed the technique of Capillary Electrophoresis.
output3: Jaroslav Heyrovsky developed the Polarimetry technique, which is a method used to measure the polarization of a sample. This technique is often used in analytical chemistry to determine the chemical composition of a substance.

question: Access cavity shape in mandibular 1st molar with 4 canals
prompt:
Access cavity shape in mandibular 1st molar with 4 canalsA)Trapezoidal
B)Round
C)Oval
D)Triangular
output0: The mandibular 1st molar with 4 canals typically has a trapezoidal-shaped access cavity. This shape allows the dentist to easily access the canals and perform the necessary treatment.
output1: The access cavity shape in the mandibular 1st molar with 4 canals is typically round. This shape allows for easy access to the canal orifices and facilitates cleaning and shaping of the canal.
output2: The access cavity shape in the mandibular 1st molar with 4 canals is typically oval. This shape allows for easy access to the canals and helps to minimize the risk of instrument breakage or damage to the tooth structure.
output3: The access cavity shape in the mandibular 1st molar with 4 canals is triangular. This shape allows for better access to the entire tooth, including the mesial and distal canals, and is ideal for performing a complete root canal treatment.

question: Gas gangrene skin colour changes to
prompt:
Gas gangrene skin colour changes toA)Red
B)Purple
C)Pink
D)Yellowish
output0: Gas gangrene skin colour changes to red because the bacteria that cause it produce toxins that cause the skin to become inflamed and reddened.
output1: Gas gangrene skin color changes to purple due to the presence of bacteria in the tissue that produce gas and cause the skin to turn purple.
output2: Gas gangrene skin colour changes to pink because the bacteria that cause it produce a toxin that damages the skin and causes it to become pink or red.
output3: Gas gangrene skin colour changes to yellowish because of the presence of a toxin called gas gangrene toxin. This toxin causes the skin to become yellowish, and it is a common sign of gas gangrene.

question: Aggressive periodontitis differs from chronic periodontitis as the former has?
options: C)Presence bacterial deposits and severity of periodontal breakdown are clinically relevant
prompt:
Aggressive periodontitis differs from chronic periodontitis as the former has?A)Bone destruction is very fast
B)Narrow bone less
C)Presence bacterial deposits and severity of periodontal breakdown are clinically relevant
D)Highly systemic conditions
output0: Aggressive periodontitis differs from chronic periodontitis in that the former has very fast bone destruction. This is because the bacteria that cause aggressive periodontitis are more virulent and produce more toxins, which leads to a more rapid progression of the disease.
output1: Aggressive periodontitis differs from chronic periodontitis in that it is characterized by a narrow bone defect. In contrast to chronic periodontitis, which is characterized by a more widespread bone destruction, aggressive periodontitis is marked by a narrow, localized bone defect.
output2: Aggressive periodontitis is characterized by a more rapid progression of periodontal breakdown and the presence of bacterial deposits, which are clinically relevant and contribute to the severity of the condition. In contrast, chronic periodontitis progresses more slowly and the bone loss is less pronounced.
output3: Aggressive periodontitis is a condition where the periodontal tissues are affected rapidly and severely, leading to rapid bone destruction and tooth loss. This condition is often associated with systemic conditions such as diabetes, obesity, and immunosuppression.

question: In Schwann cells, Mycobacterium leprae divides after–
prompt:
In Schwann cells, Mycobacterium leprae divides after–A)2 – 3days
B)12 – 13days
C)22 – 23days
D)33 – 43days
output0: Mycobacterium leprae divides after 2-3 days in Schwann cells, which is why this technique is effective in treating leprosy.
output1: Mycobacterium leprae divides after approximately 12 – 13 days in Schwann cells. This is because the bacteria are able to exploit the cell's metabolic resources to replicate and divide.
output2: Mycobacterium leprae divides after approximately 22-23 days in Schwann cells.
output3: Mycobacterium leprae divides after 33 – 43 days in Schwann cells, which provides a long window of opportunity for the immune system to detect and respond to the infection.

question: 29. Treatment of cyanosis congenital heart disease conventional surgical Blalock-Taussig shunt formula (Blalock-Taussig shunt), that are mainly connected to the following two vessels, in order to achieve the effect of improving hypoxia?
correct_answer: Ipsilateral subclavian artery and the pulmonary artery (Subclavian artery and pulmonary artery of the same side)
options: A)Subclavian artery and pulmonary vein ipsilateral (Subclavian artery and pulmonary vein of the same side)
B)Ascending aorta and pulmonary artery (Ascending aorta and main pulmonary artery)
C)Pulmonary artery and the ipsilateral carotid artery (Carotid artery and subclavian artery of the same side)
D)Ipsilateral subclavian artery and the pulmonary artery (Subclavian artery and pulmonary artery of the same side)
prompt:
29. Treatment of cyanosis congenital heart disease conventional surgical Blalock-Taussig shunt formula (Blalock-Taussig shunt), that are mainly connected to the following two vessels, in order to achieve the effect of improving hypoxia?
A)Subclavian artery and pulmonary vein ipsilateral (Subclavian artery and pulmonary vein of the same side)
B)Ascending aorta and pulmonary artery (Ascending aorta and main pulmonary artery)
C)Pulmonary artery and the ipsilateral carotid artery (Carotid artery and subclavian artery of the same side)
D)Ipsilateral subclavian artery and the pulmonary artery (Subclavian artery and pulmonary artery of the same side)
output0: The Blalock-Taussig shunt is a surgical procedure used to treat cyanosis congenital heart disease. The procedure involves connecting the subclavian artery and pulmonary vein of the same side to improve oxygenation of the body. This technique is effective in improving hypoxia because it allows oxygenated blood to bypass the blocked or narrowed pulmonary veins and reach the lungs more directly.
output1: The Blalock-Taussig shunt is a surgical procedure used to treat cyanosis congenital heart disease. The shunt is created by connecting the ascending aorta to the pulmonary artery, which allows blood to bypass the patent ductus arteriosus and flow directly to the lungs. This procedure is effective in improving hypoxia in children with cyanosis congenital heart disease.
output2: The Blalock-Taussig shunt is a surgical procedure used to treat cyanosis congenital heart disease. This shunt is created by connecting the pulmonary artery to the ipsilateral carotid artery, which is a branch of the aortic arch. This allows oxygenated blood from the aorta to be directed to the lungs, improving hypoxia.
output3: The Blalock-Taussig shunt is a surgical procedure used to treat cyanosis congenital heart disease. The shunt is created by connecting the subclavian artery to the pulmonary artery, allowing blood to bypass the obstruction in the pulmonary circulation and improve oxygenation of the body. Therefore, the correct answer is D)Ipsilateral subclavian artery and the pulmonary artery (Subclavian artery and pulmonary artery of the same side).
